posts.cooked: Before the spring cleaning, there was a feature request to be able to use Google Photos to attach something to a message. It sure would be nice to be able to do that.

posts.cooked: Agreed, this is a huge inconvenience and Google Photos is probably the leading cloud photo storage service used by Android. Not being able to easily share photos I have taken (that are no longer stored locally) is a huge inconvenience. You have to do the reverse now and open Google Photos, then share it to Signal

ChrisG683:

share photos I have taken (that are no longer stored locally)

Are you asking for Signal to download the photo onto your device when attached to a message, or send a link to the Google-hosted photo?

mds08011:

Are you asking for Signal to download the photo onto your device when attached to a message, or send a link to the Google-hosted photo?

Normally, Google Photos should just appear in the selection dialog when attaching a photo, I think.

haffenloher:

Normally, Google Photos should just appear in the selection dialog when attaching a photo, I think.

They are referring to a photo which is not stored on their device. I am not sure how attaching would work in this situation. Wouldn‚Äôt the photo need to be downloaded before it can be attached?

mds08011:

Wouldn‚Äôt the photo need to be downloaded before it can be attached?

I guess Google Photos would do that transparently in the background, without Signal having to worry about it.

If I recall correctly, when you select Google Photos from the side bar it pulls the thumbnails from your cloud listing; selecting an image downloads it (if it‚Äôs not already cached on your phone) and attaches it.

I think the only way to generate links is to share it from within Google Photos itself.

The Signal devs shouldn‚Äôt have to worry about this detail though, all they need to do is simply link Google Photos as a valid attachment source. Signal currently has Google Drive listed, but that‚Äôs not very useful when trying to attach an image!

It seems like a whole section is missing, the second section is the generic list that all apps get it looks like, but the third section looks like apps that provide gallery searching hooks.

I have attached some images below showing the feature that is missing from Signal that most other messaging apps implement when choosing ‚ÄúAttach -> Gallery‚Äù

Here‚Äôs what Signal‚Äôs menu looks like

Signal.png1440√ó2880 121 KB

Here‚Äôs what Android Messages‚Äô menu looks like

Android_Messages.png1440√ó2880 144 KB
Thank you for the clarification! I hadn‚Äôt realized Google Photos could do that.

So with the latest update to Signal with multi-image support we‚Äôre even further away from being able to select items from Google Photos since they implemented their own gallery that only shows local device folders. If you have photos that are only in the cloud on Google Photos you have to manually download them to your device first, or else share them one-by-one from the Google Photos app (since Signal doesn‚Äôt allow multiple attachments to be shared from apps).

Herohtar:

(since Signal doesn‚Äôt allow multiple attachments to be shared from apps).

Solving this bit is probably the way to go here, right? I guess other in-app galleries (e.g. Whatsapp‚Äôs) don‚Äôt show in-the-cloud images, either?

That is correct, WhatsApp does not show images that are not saved on the device but only in Google Photos in the cloud.
In the image picker, WhatsApp allows to switch to a Google Photos image picker (and others) though, which than of course includes those cloud images. The option is available in a context menu in the top right of the image picker.

haffenloher:

I guess other in-app galleries (e.g. Whatsapp‚Äôs) don‚Äôt show in-the-cloud images, either?

I can‚Äôt speak for WhatsApp, but from what @ShatteredMotion said it sounds like it gives an option to open the system image selector that can access Google Photos.

From my quick checks of messaging apps that I do have immediate access to, Allo, Hangouts, and Facebook Messenger also all have their own image roll or gallery, but they all provide an option to bring up the system image selector with access to Google Photos and other options. Facebook Messenger even has a ‚ÄúGoogle Photos‚Äù option in its internal image folder list that immediately brings up the Google Photos image selection screen (not sure how that works?)

So it seems there is still an avenue for Signal to follow here for implementing this.

posts.cooked:
toby_mole:

(Moreso that I can‚Äôt figure out how to get an image from google photos to show up in the gallery in signal, but this shouldn‚Äôt even be an issue)

You can download a photo from Google Photos by swiping up on an image in Google Photos and tapping on ‚ÄòDownload‚Äô. From there you should be able to set it as your profile picture in Signal.

Let me know if you need anymore help with this.
:)

9to5Google ‚Äì 13 Feb 24

Android photo picker with Google Photos support rolling out via February...

Google is officially rolling out support for Google Photos and other cloud backup apps in the Android photo picker...

Est. reading time: 3 minutes

This is an even better solution. The native photo picker will have support for cloud services.

link_counts.title: Android photo picker with Google Photos support rolling out

posts.cooked:
This is requested here:

Implement Android's Photo Picker Android Feature Requests
Currently, order to attach pictures or video to a message in Signal for Android, the user must grant the app access to photos and media on the device, after they choose on add and choose on ‚ÄúGallery‚Äù. This provides Signal access to all photos, videos, and audio files on the phone thereafter. On Android 11+, Photo Picker (Photo picker  |  Android Developers) is available, which prompts the user to select the photo(s) and video(s), and the app will then only have access to those additional files‚Ä¶
